<lname>McIlroy</lname> wins 800m indoor title

<name>James McIlroy</name> motored to the AAA's Indoor 800m title in Sheffied on Sunday in a time of one minute, 47.97 seconds.

The Larne athlete dominated the race from start to finish although he had to hold off a late challenge from Welshman <name>Jimmy Watkins</name> in the final 100 metres. "I had to go out and go through all the gears before the Europeans and I won't run again until then," said <lname>McIlroy</lname>. ''I though if I got lucky I'd get close to the British record but I blew up in the end.'' <lname>McIlroy</lname> has been in superb form at the start of the season and will now start his build-up for the European Indoors at Madrid on 4-6 March. Meanwhile, <name>Paul Brizzel</name> and <name>Anna Boyle</name> reached the semi-finals of the 60m hurdles with Boyle setting a season's best of 7.48. In the women's 60m final, <name>Ailis McSweeney</name> broke <name>Michelle Carroll</name>'s long-standing Irish record by clocking 7.37 which left her in third place. <name>David Gillick</name> showed that he is a genuine medal contender in the European Indoor Championships by claiming an impressive 400m victory. <lname>Gillick</lname> was more than half-a-second clear when taking gold in 46.45 - .02 outside his personal best set in Saturday's semi-finals.

The Irishman is now the fastest European this season. <name>Derval O'Rourke</name> broke her own Irish 60m hurdles record by clocking 8.06 which left her third behind new British record holder <name>Sarah Claxton</name> (7.96). <name>James Nolan</name> (3:46.04) took second in the men's 1500m behind <name>Neil Speaight</name> (3:45.86) but the Offaly man was outside the European Indoor standard. <name>Colin Costello</name> was seventh in the 1500m final in 3:48.82). <name>Deirdre Ryan</name> was second in the women's high jump with a clearance of 1.87m while <name>Aoife Byrne</name> took silver in the 800m in a personal best of 2:06.73. Lisburn's <name>Kelly McNeice Reid</name> (4:31.34) was seventh in the women's 1500m while <name>Gary Murray</name> (8:11.22) was 11th in the men's 3000m. Meanwhile, <name>Stephen Cairns</name> and <name>Jill Shannon</name> claimed the individual titles at Saturday's Northern Ireland Cross Country Championship in <lname>Coleraine</lname>. <fname>Cairns</fname> came in ahead of <name>Paul Rowan</name> and <name>Allan Bogle</name> in the men's race. <lname>Willowfield</lname> claimed their first men's team title in 72 years while <fname>Shannon</fname> helped Lagan Valley win the women's team honours.
